data.title: Fix jumpy zooming when panning and zooming
data.body: I noticed an issue where if you zoom (2 finger pinch), then let go of one finger, pan around, then zoom again, the second zoom would jump in the very beginning. This seems to be caused by the fact that pointer1 and pointer2 are only updated in touchDragged if pinching is true. Moving the update calls outside of the pinching if statement solves the issue for me. I haven't noticed any regressions from this change.

data.title: GWT Reflection extension + Filehandle bugfix
data.body:
Add capability to extend GWT reflection with GdxReflect annotation
Bug fix in GWT relative file paths (wrong '/' prepend)

data.title: Fixed setColor of Pixmap GWT emulation
data.body: The color was used as ARGB and if should be used as RGBA.

data.title: Adding support for the HTTP verbs PUT and DELETE
data.body:
This adds the support for the PUT and DELETE HttpMethods to Net.HttpRequest.

Tested on Android and desktop, iOS not tested but should be OK.

data.title: Fix for HTTP error responses being handled as failed requests
data.body:
The documentation for the Net.HttpResponseListener.failed method states:
"Called if the Net.HttpRequest failed because an exception when processing the HTTP request, could be a timeout any other reason (not an HTTP error)."

However, HTTP errors are currently being treated as failures. This makes it impossible to get at the error body the server sends. For example a server may give a JSON response on 400-level status that the client has to parse and take action on.

The proposed fix does the following:
On HTTP errors, set the HttpClientResponse input stream to the error stream. This continues the response processing and allows for reading the server's error response in the handleHttpResponse callback instead of invoking the failed method (which is now used for connection-level failures like the timeouts, the server not being reachable etc).

data.title: New3dapi: Rename MeshPartMaterial to NodePart
data.body:
That seems like a better name.

Also some small other changes:

JsonModelLoader: i'll add a PR to fbx-conv to reflect these changes, just need to cleanup things and decide on skinning. The changes are:
- Mesh doesnt have to have an id (its referenced by its mesh parts)
- Material doesnt have to a type ATM (its currently implied by having specular attributes)
- Translation, rotation, scale aren't required (only need to be included if actually changed)
- Break current g3dj files: rename array of materials in node to parts.
- Use ColorUnpacked for color attributes (note that the current fbx-conv only export rgb(3), this will be fixed by my PR)

ModelInstance: Add userData, I remember discussing it, but not sure what we decided. Either way I had it in my branch, but can be removed easily.

data.title: Issue 815, 1407 EarClippingTriangulator
data.body:
previous pull request for issue 815 ( with description ) - https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/326
issue 1407 -  'minArea' - value for most accurate calculations ( must be a negative and should be close to zero ). It's need here because may be returned a small mistakes in concave / not concave by #getCrsArea ( for similar cases ). For this case i use a 1.0E-7 ( and this will be default ). In other cases where vertices are not so nearly 'minArea' can be changed to zero. I think this a most simple and **optimal** decision.

data.title: Add ShaderProgram method to set a mat3 uniform from a FloatBuffer.
data.body: This is similar to the mat4 method I added earlier. I discovered that I was running out of uniforms for my character armature animation shaders, so I modified my code to use mat3s for the normals and mat4s for the positions.

data.title: Update TiledMapTileSet - get TileSet tiles when TiledMapTile ID is unknown
data.body:
Premise:
I am using Tiled Map Editor and giving properties, such as friction, to individual TileSet tiles as a template so that I may lay down 20 'ice' tiles and 20 'road' tiles without having to individually specify their respective properties (friction) for each tile laid as that would get cumbersome. 

TileSets support properties for their Tiles, and libgdx allows access to these TileSets, however the TileSet class only allows access to their respective Tiles (and their respective properties) if you know the exact id of said Tile.

Current State:
- You may iterate through all the TiledMapTileSets for a given TileMap.
- For each TileSet, if you DO know the TiledMapTile's id, you may get TiledMapTile's from the TileSet using TileSet.getId(id). 
- If you DO NOT know the id of the TiledMapTile, there is no way to iterate through all of its TiledMapTile's - such is my case since the user may make their own levels and the ids they may use are unknown to me

data.title: new3dapi: refactor lighting
data.body:
Also some minor other changes.

Note that I made ShaderProgram#fetchUniformLocation public, required to access the ambient cubemap.

When constructing the DefaultShader you can provide the number of directional and point light (and spot light, which does nothing atm) which will be send to the shader. For all lights on top of that an ambient cubemap is used.

data.title: remove the use of deprecated #mul()
data.body: *and some unused imports in "pax-britannica"

data.title: New3dapi: various changes
data.body:
DefaultShader: 
Check the vertex attributes on construction/canrender. I.e. the previous implementation assumed that a mesh had a normal attribute, which results in strange behaviour if it didnt. This solution is still not ideal (it only allows one attrbiute for each usage), but better than nothing.

MeshBuilder/MeshPartBuilder: 
- Add setColor which is used for the color attribute (if available) and no vertex color is specified.
- Add primitiveType to begin and part, this allows to create multiple meshparts with different primitive types on the same mesh.
- Require a position attribute and add posSize/colSize, allowing 2d vetices and colors without alpha.
- Add hasPosition/hasNormal/hasColor/hasUV to VertexInfo.
- Add/modify some helper methods like line/triangle/rect and also by index. The sphere/cone/cylinder methods still need to be optimized though.

Tests:
- Add a base test with a grid/axes and only delegates the actual rendering for easy testing.
- Use MeshBuilder instead of ShapeRenderer so the mesh is cached.
- Add a base test which displays fps and allows to select a model for easy testing.
- Update NewModelTest to use that.

This should help for easier testing lighting/shaders.

data.title: Added convenient setColor methods for decal.
data.body: Added setColor for decal (the same as Sprite and Spritebatch) uses. Sorry for pull request noise, but manged to branch out from existing feature branch.

data.title: Setting decal color
data.body: I missed the convenient setColor-methods (in sprite and spritebatch), so I added them in Decal as well.

data.title: Replaced ArrayList with the internal libgdx Array.
data.body:
Maybe there is a good reason why Box2D uses ArrayList instead of libgdx.utils.Array, but I figured I could try with a pull request nevertheless.

This could potential break the API for people, if they rely a lot on body.getFixtureList() for instance.

data.title: Fixed forceVBO in Mesh
data.body:
At least one recent commit https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/commit/7020231ca8b1e14995d398603de525581e3d1282 has completely disabled VBO support in the SpriteBatch class for not so clear reasons. 
My project uses GL20 for now only and I would like to use/test VBOs, so at least there's a way to bring back VBOs in spritebatch by using the forceVBO flag.

If someone could clarify why SpriteBatch was changed I would appreciate as well. 
Reason being is that setting a new texture for every draw can be the cause of the slow down instead of the vbo itself. 
Eg: Some engines can sort the meshes by material before drawing, minimizing state changes for performance reasons.

Also one thing not taken into account in the SpriteBatch class is culling with GL_CULL_FACE which could theoretically help with performance. Spritebatch uses a (non default) CW front face order (default is CCW as front face), which makes things a little bit uneasy if you have mixed usage with other custom CCW meshes, but that's a non issue.
